+badmuthasuka  As per the US Census #'s;
NYC's average population <excepting NY county> is +/- 170,000 persons per 
cubic mile. In Manhattan the numbers run between 230-270 per cubic mile. 
NYC is a 24/7/365 town with a public transit system that carries daily 
between 6 & 9 million riders daily on 24 lines with 463 stations. we have 5 
boro's and some 43 islands which make-up this city. with well over 400 
neighborhoods or towns cobbled together into 1 very large city.
Welcome to NYC, it's been waiting for you.-Taylor Swift 2014.

top_comment.text:
For anyone who lives in NYC, how can you tell when you're in a different 
neighborhood? I've wanted to know this question for so long. In LA, we have 
signs that look like this, with each neighborhood having its own sign. All 
of them look like this: 
http://static.panoramio.com/photos/large/25791278.jpg
What's it like for NYC?﻿
top_comment.author: Julius Escano

comments.text:
+Clarke Erskine Well that was a detailed response! Every now and then 
Carson is on the local news channel because of some murder or shooting or 
whatever. Asides from the gang graffiti and gunshots I heard that one time, 
I live in a fairly safe area of Carson. I don't worry about bullets going 
through my walls.
Interesting trivia for you. There's a gang that's notorious in the L.A. 
area(or at least in the harbor area, where I live)that claims west 204th 
street in the harbor gateway neighborhood of L.A. It's called 204th street 
gang or V204ST(V stands for Varrio). They're notorious for racial killings. 
If you ever watched the show Gangland, look up the episode race wars. 
You'll learn a bit more about them.
comments.author: Julius Escano

comments.text:
IN REPLY;
MY BUILDING IS WHAT IS KNOWN AS A "MITCHELL-LAMA CO-OP" THE BUILDING WAS
BUILT IN 1963,AND FULLY OCCUPIED BY THE END OF 1964. IT IS A PRIVATELY
OWNED/OCCUPIED RESIDENCE.
THE BUILDINGS ACROSS THE STREET ARE RENTALS BUILT IN 1904, WHEN THE SUBWAY
BEGAN OPERATIONS,......THE WOODS ARE CITY PARKLAND "HIGH-BRIDGE PARK".
THE "PROJECTS" AKA "PUBLIC HOUSING "ARE IN THE INWOOD NEIGHBORHOOD ON A
SUPER BLOCK(Dyckman St. + 10th avenue = Nagle Ave + west 204th street)
THEY'RE PROPER NAME IS "THE DYCKMAN HOUSES" NAMED FOR THE FAMILY FARM UPON
WHICH THEY ARE SITUATED. #1 SUBWAY LINE @ DYCKMAN ST-STOP. ZIP CODE 10034.
THEY WERE BUILT IN 1952 BY THE NYC HOUSING AUTHORITY.
AS TO THE GRAFFITTI...FUNNY BUT CURRENT LAW ALLOW'S FOR PRIVATELY OWNED
PROPERTIES TO MAKE THEIR OWN RULES ABOUT WEATHER OR NOT CHOSEN ARTISTS CAN
PLACE THEIR WORK ON DESIGNATED AREA'S OF SAID FACILITY. THE PERMISSION
DOCUMENT MUST BE FILED WITH THE CITY ART COMMISSION.

GUN SHOTS..TO A CITY PERSON/RESIDENT ARE A SIGN OF IMMINENT
POPULATION/ECONOMIC SHIFT IN PROGRESS, AND ABOUT TO MAKE THE FINAL CHANGE,
ITS CALLED DRUG-GANG RELATED VIOLENCE, "NORMAL-WORKING PEOPLE" GENERALLY
SHOULD BE AND ARE LITTLE CONCERNED, BUT NOT BY ANY REAL AMOUNT.
MY INCOME , MINIMUM WAGE. I AM HOUSEKEEPING STAFF IN A SMALL CHAIN
SUPERMARKET.
comments.author: Clarke Erskine

comments.text:
+Clarke Erskine Don't you live in housing projects? That's ghetto bro! Also 
when I saw your building I turned the screen and saw a wall full of 
graffiti. I myself live in a somewhat seedy area. I see gang graffiti every 
now and then. Not dangerous, just a bit seedy. I've only heard gunshots 
once in 4 years of living in Carson. What's the name of your neighborhood 
anyway?  Have you ever heard gunshots in your neighborhood? And what's your 
yearly income?
And yeah man you're right, I need to make high school memorable. I'm just 
in my 9th week of 9th grade so I got plenty of time, but I need to make 
something happen.
comments.author: Julius Escano

comments.text:
jules;
I guess that since my neighborhood is over 100 years of age , it looks to
be a bit worn.......I wouldn't say ghetto(define) neighborhood. however if
you view hudson-heights/ ft. washington (10033/40) things might look to be
/appear as newer....appearances are deceiving, the ages of the buildings
are exactly the same, but the incomes are different-as well as the
ethnicities. Broadway is the income/racial "mason-dixon" line. Notice all
the parks, and smallness of the area. Do the same study for your olde birth
address, and you are in for a surprise,.........you were born in a
neighborhood of the same age and income as mine is today- that address is
the same as when you moved out 15+ years ago.
How's your new school treating you.... make the fullest use of this time of
your life, as "these are the good olde days-now today, this moment" in 3
years you become an adult, it's a very sobering world out here.
See you soon.
comments.author: Clarke Erskine

comments.text:
+Clarke Erskine I know. I searched up your zip code right now. You live in 
a ghetto neighborhood huh? My address is 20703 Shearer Ave., Carson, CA. My 
zip code is 90745.
comments.author: Julius Escano

comments.text:
Have you ever thought of googlei-up that address and seeing what the
building looks like today/now....as to me my address is 17 ft. george hill,
nyc i live on a very wooded hill between two neighborhoods- Washington-hts/
Ft. George & Inwood, in very upper-manhattan. i live directly on top of the
#1 line subway.
comments.author: Clarke Erskine

comments.text:
+Clarke Erskine Well to be honest with you that definitely won't happen for 
a while. I'm actually in high school if you didn't know. And I'm a 
freshman. So I won't see the city for some time, I know that. But my 
original address was 1733 Williamsbridge Rd., Bronx, NY. If you're curious 
as to where I live now, I live in Carson, CA. Carson actually isn't L.A., 
but it's right next to the port neighborhoods of L.A. It's a city of L.A. 
county that's right in the port area and 10 min. away from south L.A. Also 
Carson is served by LAUSD and LAPD, so I guess I can say it's Los Angeles 
enough.
comments.author: Julius Escano

comments.text:
jules;
I live and work on manhattan island "THE-CITY"; MY JOB ZIP CODE IS 10001,
MY RESIDENCE IS 10040.
HEY, NEXT TIME YOU'RE PLANNING TO/ARE VISITING YOUR BIRTH-CITY......RING ME
UP, PLS. WE CAN GO AND EXPLORE THIS TOWN, YOUR ORIGINAL ADDRESS,.... AND
........THE REST OF THE CITY. MARCH 1ST, 2015 THE NEW #7 LINE
"HUDSON-YARDS" TERMINUS OPENS.
comments.author: Clarke Erskine

comments.text:
+Clarke Erskine You know actually I didn't look up any of those links you 
gave me LOL! I just looked at Google maps to see the neighborhoods. I was 
really impressed with the clear boundaries Manhattan has. And again, I'm 
actually from New York but moved to L.A. at a young age. To me L.A. is home 
but I still love New York. I will come back to the city of my birth one 
day. This time to tour around the boroughs. By the way, which borough do 
you live in?
comments.author: Julius Escano

& YOU'RE WELCOME.
comments.author: Clarke Erskine

comments.text:
+Clarke Erskine Well I like your speech about NYC. I like the clear 
boundaries too. For LA I like making approximate boundaries for 
neighborhoods so they're easier for me to understand. Also Manhattan has 
perhaps the easiest boundaries to understand of any place in the U.S. It's 
so easy to tell when you're in lower, midtown, the UES/UWS, and upper 
Manhattan. Google maps shows such clear boundaries I can memorize it like 
that.
comments.author: Julius Escano

comments.text:
In Reply ;
Okay, allow me to be really clear, ; nyc is a very large and busy place,
there are to too many people here, this town is a rer place in that it is
made of 5 counties/boroughs, there are within the city's boundries & approx
10.6 + million people of every color. belief, income, nation, language,
ethnic group.
only 10% of us have driver's licenses & own our own vehicles, the main
means of transport around this region is via public-mass-transit, this is a
24/7/365 kinda town. on all maps of the region, every neighborhoods
boundries are noted the names, and centers also. when in doubt ask a
native..or go online to;" nycgo.com/neighborhoods" ; and" nyc.gov/info".
Now that you have the key's to unlocking the city, go and get the
information that you seek.
comments.author: Clarke Erskine

comments.text:
+Julius Escano ; In answer to your clarification question about NYC- there 
are over 10mm residents in this town, and we never ever sleep, each borough 
has many distinct neighborhoods and area's within, there are 5 
borough's/counties 504 subway stations, 400+ bus lines, 25 subway lines 9+ 
area codes and over, 100 zip codes, if one of us cannot answer a 
question-another will step-up with the right answer to a visitor's question 
on anything NYC.  Welcome to the Big Apple, enjoy your visit , we thank you 
for taking the time out of your life to check our town out. Thank you.
comments.author: Clarke Erskine

comments.text:
+Clarke Erskine What if they don't know? Then what? I just like it when 
there's a sign that tells the neighborhood' name, that's all.
comments.author: Julius Escano

comments.text: MAYBE...JUST SIMPLY WALK UP TO SOME PERSON AND ASK..??
comments.author: Clarke Erskine

comments.text:
+Vitor Hugo Penna I like that there's clear boundaries, but what I'm 
saying is I like when you can actually know the name of your neighborhood 
without looking at google maps or city data or whatever.
comments.author: Julius Escano

comments.text:
The roads mark the boundaries in between a, there is no signage because 
it's not needed
comments.author: Vitor Hugo Penna

comments.text:
+Clarke Erskine LOL I'm actually from New York! I'm from Morris Park in the 
Bronx. I just don't know anything about the neighborhoods in New York. I 
know a good amount of names for neighborhoods in every borough, but that's 
after I left New york. I don't know much about the city out of 
experience because I didn't live there long. Just 6 years. And that's when 
I was really young. I just wanted to see how it differs from over here in 
Los Angeles. But I would love to come back to New York. This time to 
explore every borough. Thanks!
comments.author: Julius Escano

comments.text:
To best answer your question; Go to; http;nyc.go/neighborhoods       We 
residents<local's> know almost by instinct..........but there are maps; 
available to all; The Zip-Code maps are a great beginning. No 
signs.......except in ; STATEN ISLAND, BROOKLYN, THE BRONX, AND QUEENS, the 
neighborhoods/towns are well known by almost all, just ask !
Enjoy your visit and of course thank you for visiting my hometown.
comments.author: Clarke Erskine

top_comment.text:
if new Yorkers like new York so much, they need to STAY 'in' NEW YORK.  
They're so rude.  if they don't like the way southerners do things, they 
need to stay up there. You can live right next door to one for 10 years and 
when you say hey to 'em they'll say I don't know you fool.  what it boils 
down to is in most cases they need their tails kicked.  they act 
like asking to sit on the same bench isn't minding your own business.  if 
you new Yorkers don't like the south, then I beg you, you like new York, 
delaware, etc. right .  Well, i'll think you kindly, to stay up there to 
make you and I BOTH happy as eef. ok? ok.﻿
top_comment.author: David “Mario” Murray

comments.text:
+Clarke Erskine in response to everything you say after this and in

comments.author: David “Mario” Murray

comments.text:
IN REPLY TO COMMENT;
TO SPEND TIME IN NYC, IS TO BEGIN TO UNDERSTAND...HERE ARE THE CENSUS #S- 
IN NYC 5 BORO'S AVG IS 138K FOLKS PER SQ MILE, IN MANHATTAN THE AVG IS OVER 
170K FOLKS PER SQ MILE. NO PERSON IS SPECIAL, GROW UP. WE ARE ALL EACH 
OTHERS FELLOW NEIGHBORS.
comments.author: Clarke Erskine

comments.text:
Next time instead of waving just flip em off. They will smile and embrace 
you with you with open arms. Rudeness. New Yorkers love it.
comments.author: DJR5280

comments.text: Just ignore them...
comments.author: Brian Yatsuko

comments.text:
Thats probably New Yorker for you. But you need to understand why the 
culture is like that. New York is a big city, and a proper city unlike 
Dallas, (which is a huge village). So people are busy,there is traffic, 
 people are diverse, its hard to understand each other and you already 
there are people speaking more than 100s of languages. But there is nothing 
you can't do in New York. New York is the Center of America, the heart and 
soul of America. The number of tourists that visit New York speaks for 
itself. Nobody hates the South. New Yorkers think they are at the center of 
the World, which is kinda true. New York is a world capital and nobody has 
the time to think about South or even Saudi Arabia.
comments.author: adad

comments.text: +Clarke Erskine you knew what I meant
comments.author: David “Mario” Murray

comments.text:
In reply; I'm a native born f/t resident of NYC; As a resident  i'd note ; 
It is all in your personal demeanor which we pick-up on and react too. 
There are on any given day an average of over 170k people per square mile 
on manhattan, or 2.5 million residents, 1,75 million "tourists", and 4.5 
million workers at anytime just on manhattan, bklyns #'s are 3mm alone. Get 
it?? Be nice & get nice.
Thanks for taking the time to visit NYC we thank you.
comments.author: Clarke Erskine

comments.text: I have a head it ends in a point, pointy pointy pointy, pointy pointy point
comments.author: Jay Kay

comments.text:
+Jay Kay if that were the case, I wouldn't feel the need to say anything 
against the majority of northerners.  don't get me wrong, I have some very 
good friends from places up there that would do anything in the world for 
anyone, one's probably a youth pastor by now.  but you have to admit, I got 
a point.
comments.author: David “Mario” Murray

comments.text:
You sound like you've had a bad experience one time and u need to take it 
out on 8 million people. Nice southern charm.
comments.author: Jay Kay

comments.text:
+SUNRISE KINGDOM no offense, but...I wouldn't call that a reason to call 
the police on your next door neighbor for waving at you or for your 
neighbor waving at you on the same block.
comments.author: David “Mario” Murray

comments.text:
I live in NYC and it's a apartment and yes our residents are crankey at 
times everyone is
comments.author: Sunrise Films

comments.text:
+SUNRISE KINGDOM all I'm saying is this:  they come down here and I'll wave 
at them and they'll call the police because I waved at them.  Down here we 
don't have a lot of side walks so there's an ordinance where you can walk 
on the edge of peoples' yards (and people down here don't care anyway)(and 
it's not like they don't know this because they get a booklet explaining 
the town ordinances) and they'll curse at me and call the police.  To the 
people in the stores that are cashiers they'll curse out the cashiers 
because of the sales tax and say "I pay my taxes!!!'  They might do 
something like literally live right next door to you for 10 years straight 
and then when they move up the street less than half a block for about 2 
months and you see them again they'll say:  'I don't know you fool!'.  All 
I'm saying is I've had all kinds of bad experiences with people from the 
northern region of our country and I don't appreciate the way I've or 
others have been treated by them.  that's all I'm saying.
comments.author: David “Mario” Murray

comments.text: Maybe because southern like you are the rude ones
comments.author: Sunrise Films

comments.text:
And it wasn't New York City or New York who decided to "give it away", it 
was the Supreme Court in the capital who decided. Alright?
comments.author: Vitor Hugo Penna

comments.text:
It is still completely against New Jersey's regulations, same thing with 
Ellis Island, the building itself belongs to New York and the land it's on 
belongs to New Jersey. If they show just the building floating around on 
nothing but water than that's alright, but they cannot show the land. It's 
called "protected", same way it is illegal to show the original World Trade 
Center in a photo animation thingy without it being the main focus.
comments.author: Vitor Hugo Penna

comments.text:
+Vitor Hugo Penna I remember when it came out on the news but do you really 
believe New York City is going to let one of its biggest landmarks just go 
to another state?
comments.author: OnlyTheTruthSorry

comments.text:
It will be technically against state regulations because the Statue of 
Liberty is on New Jersey territory, not New York. It's popular belief that 
it's in New York, but it is in fact in New Jersey.
comments.author: Vitor Hugo Penna

comments.text:
You sound like a professional advertiser or spokesman or something for New 
York city haha. But thanks for the information :) you said some interesting 
things about New York.
comments.author: Kurt  Bauer

comments.text:
+Kurt Bauer
Well,..NYC is alike Venice Italy....as it is made up of ! mainland Borough, 
and the rest of the town is located on an a bunch of islands it is also a 
24/7/365 town...a car is not needed here as public transit covers the 
entire city, region..with unmatched service....there are 450 neighborhoods 
that make-up NYC; the average population averages 170k per mile<in 
Manhattan its more like 280k>, when walking around 1 is very likely to run 
across multiple movie-tv crews doing thier work, also this city is 
"HOME-BASE" for the UN too....For more specific information  go to; 
NYCGO.com, or call the city government directly at 212-NEW-YORK, welcome to 
NYC, it's been waiting for you..
comments.author: Clarke Erskine

comments.text:
Everything you descirbed in your last comment just made me love New York 
even more!! I live in a small coastal area in NSW Australia, called Port 
stephens. Its about 2-3 hours up the coast from Sydney. I go to Sydney a 
few times a year to visit family and I dont mind Sydney city, its alright, 
but I love Melbourne, its a great city and Melbourne got me interested in 
the city lifestyle and since then, after lots of research, I've realized 
New York is just the best of the best when it comes to cities. Everything 
about New York really interests me and a lot of the interest came from 
seeing the city in movies and TV shows too. So with the semi affordable 
apartments your describing, like the hoods and stuff, what are they 
actually like? What are the people like there, the apartments etc? Are they 
decent quality. Sorry for all the questions, but you are really the most 
helpful person I've talked too, other people really over complicate what 
they say about the city and it can be confusing.
comments.author: Kurt  Bauer

comments.text:
so much to do and so much to see, and just the overall vibe from the city 
is enlightening. Also its a very culturally diverse city, people from all 
over the world come to NYC. and to answer your question about semi 
affordable apartments, yes you can get semi affordable apartments but you 
will most likely be in the hood, but the hoods of NYC aren't bad at all 
like they use to be, I shouldn't even call it the hood. May I ask where you 
live now?
comments.author: TRIGGA HAPPY

comments.text:
Well one of the things i found best about NYC is the fact that there is 
always somthing to do, trust me when i say this you will never have a 
boring day(unless its raining). The thing i love is the 24hr subway system, 
you can litterally go anywhere in the city when ever you want without 
having to pay 40$ on gas. When i live in NYC i didnt have a car cause i 
didnt need one. Also in NYC u are right next to everything, if youre hungry 
theres always some resturaunt or diner, if you need anything at all u 
litterally walk down the block and its like a mall.
comments.author: TRIGGA HAPPY

comments.text:
Oh and also, is there any way at all to get atleast semi affordable 
apartments? And if so how and where? Haha, because im aware that the really 
expensive costs for apartments makes it hard to live there.
comments.author: Kurt  Bauer

comments.text:
You have no idea how many questions I have haha. Seeing as I've asked for 
you to tell me the negatives of the city, this time whats the positives? I 
already have my list of reasons that New York is the best, but coming from 
someone like yourself who has lived in New York, it would be fascinating to 
see what you found great about the city :)
comments.author: Kurt  Bauer

comments.text:
+Kurt Bauer Dont get me wrong, this is by far the best city in the world in 
my oppinion...if your young or rich. But if your trying to raise a family, 
its very very stressful. If ur in the city (Manhatten, Brooklyn, Bronx) 
there is no houses so youll all be cramped in an apartment. And another 
negative is its EXTREMELY expensive, but other than that if youre young or 
rich, then its definitely the greatest city ever. Living in New York was 
one of the greatest experiances of my life. If you have any other questions 
you can ask me!
comments.author: TRIGGA HAPPY

comments.text:
+TRIGGA HAPPY I understand your point, but I suppose it just depends on how 
well you can handle a chaotic lifestyle. I would love to live there. I 
think it would be the best place to live if you were rich, because you 
could just own an amazing apartment with an awesome view and just enjoy all 
the city has to offer. But can you tell me what you dislike about the city? 
Whats its negatives, besides being crowded and chaotic?
comments.author: Kurt  Bauer

comments.text:
+Kurt Bauer Its way different living there, ive lived their for ten 
years. But yeah, very stressful and crowded. Yeah its an awesome city, and 
great for visiting, but its very stressful and chaotic living there.
comments.author: TRIGGA HAPPY

comments.text:
I haven't been to New York yet but ive always wanted to go. It looks so 
awesome and I am a huge lover of cities, always wanted to live in a city. 
New york has so much culture and things to do and see and so many great 
movies and tv shows have been set in New York. Can I ask why you dont like 
New York?? Whats the things that make you dislike it?
comments.author: Kurt  Bauer

top_comment.text:
The most unbelievable metropolis of the world.

Like a modern-day ancient Rome at its peak!

You need more-than-average money to live there though.

Personally, whenever I think NYC, first thing on my mind is always 
Manhattan, even though it's one of its 5 boroughs. Must be all the tv and 
movies. ﻿
top_comment.author: amazingdany

comments.text:
Since I live here, the issue of costs associated with the costs of being a 
tourist do not usually cross my mind...However here is a few places that  
might be of real help to you as you cost-out your planning process;
Expedia.com/NYC, NYCGO.com/visiting.., 212-NEW-YORK...NYC government 24 hrs 
phone-line.
 As a New Yorker, one thing for sure; transportation costs $ 30.00 weekly 
via the 7-day metro-card unlimited pass, second Do Not Ever Bring Your Own 
Private Vehicle into the city, as we tow for the smallest parking error 
here, and the fine can only be paid in cash.
Welcome to NYC, we've been waiting for you..
comments.author: Clarke Erskine

comments.text: OK.. but how much to just visit NYC.. without going broke.

comments.author: Expedia

captions.text:
New York is situated in the Northeast region
of the United States of America.

Over eight million people call the Big Apple
home,

and the city attracts up to fifty million
visitors a year.
Ever since the Colonists arrived in 1624,

New York has been continuously shaped by the
waves of immigrants drawn here
by the promise of hope, and liberty.

Every newcomer arrived with a cultural suitcase
that contributed to the sounds,
tastes and textures of New York.

But it is their dreams which built the city.
A city like no other!

New York touches not only the heavens with
its mythic skyline,

its influence radiates to every corner of
the globe.

Every street corner it seems, is familiar
through documentary, movie and song.

New York's straightforward grid system makes
it an easy city to explore

by foot, taxi, or on its subway, which, just
like the city - never sleeps!

In Manhattan's Midtown, you'll find many of
The Big Apple's most iconic symbols.

The Art Deco-designed Empire State Building
is one of the most impressive
and endearing skyscrapers ever created.

The skyline may have grown up around it, but
the view from the 102nd floor

is as breathtaking today as it was when it
first opened in 1931.

New York has always been a place where "when
the going got tough, the tough got going".

The Rockefeller Center, a visionary city within
a city,

rose during the darkest days of the Great
Depression.
Today, it's still a place of creativity, inspiration
and even more incredible views of the city.
Closer to earth is Grand Central Terminal.

Step into the Main Concourse, and feel the
echo of every tearful farewell

and joyous greeting throughout the station's
history.

New York has always been the gateway to the
Land of the Free,

but it is also the city of the spree - the
shopping spree!
This city is shopaholic heaven,

and Fifth Avenue with its eye-popping window
displays
is the high temple of the retail world.

Times Square - one of the most visited tourist
attractions on the planet.

Stand here, on the corner of Broadway and
Seventh Avenue,
and you stand at the crossroads of the world.

It's also the place to snap up a half-price
ticket to a Broadway show.

New York has been blessed with generous civic
spaces.

But there is no greater chill-out space in
the Big Apple than Central Park,

a beautiful 850-acre network of meadows and
lakes.

This is the place where New Yorkers come to
rest, romance, and express themselves.

Over the decades many New Yorkers made it
big,

and much of that fabulous wealth was reinvested
into collecting
some of the greatest artworks on the planet.

Nowadays, much of this art is available for
everyone to enjoy.

A walk through the The Metropolitan Museum
of Art

is a walk through 5000 years of humankind's
greatest creative moments.

The Frank Lloyd Wright designed-Guggenheim
is a different kind of walk,

one which spirals ever-upward through a dizzying
collection
of 20th and 21st Century masterpieces.

Newcomers to New York spend much of their
time looking skyward,

but since the 2001 attacks on the World Trade
Center,

a new attraction gives locals and visitors
a chance to pause and bow their heads.

The Reflecting Absence memorial and museum
honors the 3000 people

who lost their lives on that darkest of September
days.

New York resonates with the sounds of over
800 language groups,

and nothing epitomizes this diversity like
the city's neighborhoods.

Little Italy packs all the tastes and flavors
of Italy into just a couple of streets,

while Soho attracts cool cats and well-heeled
bohemians from all over the world.

A few streets away, Greenwich Village proudly
retains the cafés and bars

where creative residents like Bob Dylan first
performed before becoming American icons.
And then there are the boroughs.

Walk across the Brooklyn Bridge to the melting
pot of Brooklyn.

With its own distinctive neighborhoods, museums,
open spaces -
and who could forget Coney Island!
So welcome to New York City, The Big Apple.

We've only just given you a bite-sized taste
of what this incredible city has to offer.

But if you've got an appetite for the very
best things that life has to offer,
this is the destination for you -
there's enough to feast on here for a lifetime!�

title: New York City Vacation Travel Guide | Expedia
